title: ADAPT Protocol for Cardiac Event Risk
description: Assesses chest pain patients at 2 hours for risk of cardiac event. Uses elevated troponin, ischemic ECG changes, and TIMI risk factors to stratify patients into low and high risk categories for major adverse cardiac events at 30 days.

parameters.name: three_or_more_cad_risk_factors
parameters.description: ≥3 CAD risk factors (hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, diabetes, family history of coronary artery disease, or current smoker)

parameters.name: severe_angina
parameters.description: Severe angina (≥2 episodes in 24 hrs or persisting discomfort)

ranges.description: Low risk for major cardiac event
ranges.interpretation: 0-0.3% risk of major cardiac event in 30 days. Patient can be safely discharged from the emergency department with appropriate outpatient follow-up.

ranges.description: High risk for major cardiac event
ranges.interpretation: Elevated risk of major cardiac event in 30 days. Further cardiac evaluation and monitoring recommended. Consider cardiology consultation and hospital admission or observation.

formula: ADAPT uses a binary decision tree approach: High risk if any of the following are present: abnormal troponin at 0 or 2 hours, ischemic changes on ECG, or any TIMI risk factors (age ≥65, ≥3 CAD risk factors, known CAD, aspirin use in past 7 days, severe angina). Low risk if none of these criteria are met.
notes: ADAPT stands for Accelerated Diagnostic Protocol to Assess Patients with Chest Pain Symptoms Using Contemporary Troponins as the Only Biomarker
Protocol is designed for use at 2 hours after presentation to the emergency department
Must be used in conjunction with EDACS (Emergency Department Assessment of Chest Pain Score)
Excludes patients with obvious ST-elevation MI, cardiogenic shock, or life-threatening arrhythmias
High-sensitivity troponin assays are recommended for optimal performance
